thread.title: This spider is so HUGE it will give you nightmares forever
thread.title_full: This spider is so HUGE it will give you nightmares forever

title: This spider is so HUGE it will give you nightmares forever
text:
This spider is so HUGE it will give you nightmares forever This spider is so HUGE it will give you nightmares forever A MONSTER spider has been freaking people out after a video showing its enormous size went viral online.   
The gigantic huntsman, named Behemoth, has a leg span of almost six inches and is believed to be the biggest in Australia. 
The skin-crawling clip was uploaded by Tim Faulkner, a conservationist at the Australian Reptile Park, who was charged with measuring the massive beast. 
In the video, viewers can see how the spider got its name as it creeps out of a plastic container and then shows off its speed running super fast across sheets of white paper before vanishing. 
PH MONSTER: The huge huntsman spider is believed to be Australia's biggest 
Luckily, the huntsman was not left scurrying around inside the park’s headquarters in Somersby, New South Wales, too long. 
Mr Faulkner managed to get the spider to pose up on a pink ruler long enough to show off its huge 14cm leg span, before taking it outdoors and letting it tip-toe off on a eucalyptus tree. 
He posted on Facebook: “Behemoth the huntsman spider certainly kept myself and the keepers at the Australian Reptile Park on their toes. 
PH MEGA: The spider was let loose on a tree The world's scariest spiders Monday, 21st September 2015 Creepy crawlies! Spiders from all over the world. With eight legs and venomous fangs, spiders are some of the most hated and feared creatures to walk the planet. 1 / 33 Getty Images/Gallo Images Close-up of a red-knee tarantula in Mexico 
“We decided to release him in some nearby bushland so he could continue living his spider life.” 
In 2001, a huntsman spider with a 12-inch leg span was discovered skulking inside a cave in Laos. 
In Australia, huntsman spiders, despite having a reputation for inflicting a painful bite that can cause nausea and an irregular pulse rate, are warmly welcomed by gardeners as they eat insect pests. Related articles
